title: MakerBot releases Android app for controlling 3D printers | Trusted Reviews
description:
![makerbot android
app](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

**MakerBot has released an[Android
app](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.makerbot.mobile&hl=en),
so you can control your 3D printer from your mobile device.**

But don’t think you can start [printing a
mansion](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/3d-printed-mansion-made-in-china)
from the office and find it ready when you get home. Unfortunately, the mobile
device and 3D printer have to be on the same Wi-Fi network, which limits its
use somewhat.

However, MakerBot is planning 3G and 4G support, so you can print from
anywhere in the world. It says it will add the feature “in the near future”.

So what can you do with the app? You can start printing from your phone and
monitor how it’s going using the printer’s built-in camera. Which is handy if
you’re working on something else and don’t want to leave the room.

You can also cancel or pause prints, and change the filament, all without
leaving your chair.

MakerBot has updated its Thingiverse app too. By using it in tandem with
MakerBot Mobile, you can print directly from Thingiverse. (For the
uninitiated, Thingiverse is the online community where people upload their
designs and share what’s new.)

**Read more:** [Red Bull Racing: 3D printing is the future of
F1](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/red-bull-racing-3d-printing-is-the-
future-of-f1)

3D printing promised to be the next big thing in gadgets, letting us all make
our own objects. But so far, high prices and overcomplicated machines have
kept it a niche pursuit. We’ve seen a few [more
affordable](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/sculptify-david-
makes-3d-printing-more-affordable) machines lately. Hopefully they will help
it achieve mainstream success.

The Royal Mail also [trialled a 3D printing
service](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/royal-mail-to-trial-in-
branch-3d-printing-services) at its central London delivery office.
